rdf:Description.dcterms:title: New types of nuclear disintegrations.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Special photographic emulsions developed to record the tracks of charged particles hâve been exposed to cosmic rays at high altitudes by being carried in aircraft on trans-Atlantic flights. Total exposure times of more than 200 hours above 10,000 feet, with more than half being above 15*000 feet, were achieved, Microscopic examination of the plates disclosed a large number of nuclear disintegrations produced by cosmic rays. Detailed study of thèse disintegrations revealed several types not previously reported. Mesons were observed which produced at the end of their range a single proton, a single alpha particle, or one or more of each, and in one case, a secondary meson. Mesons were found among the particles of nuclear disintegrations. Other phenomena included the fast neutron disintegration of boron, the éjection of an alpha and a proton from nuclei, a "star" of 26 particles, and proton tracks with energies greater than 40 mev.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: An Electronic synchronous speed regulator.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This paper describes some of the development work undertaken by the author on an electronic synchronous speed regulating system for the National Research Council of Canada. Its purpose is to show how a control system of this type may be analysed by means of servomechanism theory, and the methods by which stable operation may be obtained. No originality is claimed for the principle of control or for the methods of analysis used here. However, the actual analysis of this control system and its proposed stabilization, has not, to the author1s knowledge, been covered elsewhere in the literature. The bibliography contains those articles which were used by the author to obtain an understanding of the subject, as well as those referred to in the text.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Electrical Engineering.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The degradation of polymers.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It has been observed in this laboratory (l) that the addition of potassium persulphate to a monomer-free latex of butadiene-styrene copolymer will promote a crosslinking reaction, the rate of which was directly proportional to the concentration of persulphate ion. This cross-linking reaction was thought to be due principally to the presence of unsaturation in the polymer, but there did seem to exist the possibility that even saturated hydro carbon chains might undergo similar cross-linking under certain conditions. Consequently, it seemed worth while to determine whether such a reaction might be induced to occur between saturated polymer molecules in solution in the absence of the monomer when a catalyst capable of producing free radicals is present. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The estimation of soil organic matter in soil profile studies.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Three general methods for the estimation of soil organic matter are in common use, loss on ignition, oxidation by heating in air or in oxygen with measurement of the carhon dioxide evolved, oxidation with hydrogen peroxide solution and oxidation with dichromate in acidic solution, the organic matter being estimated whether from the carbon dioxide evolved or indirectly from the quantity of dichromate reduced. None of these methods, with the exception of loss in ignition in case of certain types of soils, gives an absolute measure of the organic matter content. The loss on ignition technique is subject to many sources of error in practically all kinds of soils except in the case of very sandy or highly organic soils. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agricultural Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The living anatomy of the human lung.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In recent years there has arisen a great clinical interest in the lungs. This is evidenced by the development of special thoracic branches of medicine and surgery and the publication of periodicals devoted solely to these fields of medical science. A natural result of the increased clinical importance of the lungs has been a focusing of attention on the anatomy of these organs, but, in spite of this, little attention has been given to the possible significance of their lobation. It is surprising that this should be so, as pleuritic fusion of the pulmonary lobes is not an uncommon occurrence. It would be of practical interest to know whether the existence of these lobes has any significance, and, if so, what effect their fusion has on the function of the lungs. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Anatomy.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A High output, low voltage spread positive ion-source.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: For many years there has been a well-sustained Interest in ion-sources which are of vital importance for the efficient operation of positive ion accelerators such aa Van de Graaffs, high tension sets, and cyclotrons. In the present search two types of oscillating electron beam sources have been tried. One employs a hot filament cathode, the other a cold cathode. The hot filament source appeared to be very promising at the time. An ion output of 2 mA, containing an estimated 50% of atomic ions, was obtained from it. Difficulties such as contamination by evaporation from the filaments, a tendency toward instability, and a cathode life of only 1-2 days were observed. It is concluded, however, that these might be largely overcome. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Military policy and organization in New France.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The subject of this thesis is admittedly of so general a nature that if no limits were imposed its ramifications might well produce a work rivalling the Encyclopaedia Britannica. However, the object which I have in mind is of a much more limited nature and demands some elucidation. I have no intention of writing a comprehensive military history of the period, nor in particular of the concluding battle of the Plains of Abraham and its aftermath, if only for the negative reason that so much has already been said.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: France. Armée -- History.
Canada -- History -- To 1763 (New France)
Canada -- History, Military.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The effect of alloxan diabetes on experimental cholesterol arteriosclerosis in the rabbit.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Any study which purports to investigate the pathogenesis of arteriosclerosis must be considered of interest to both pure and applied science. There are few fields of biological research which touch upon so many fundamental problems as does this. It matters little whether one is concerned with the interfacial behavior of films, with the metabolism of lipids, with the behavior of extracellular protein, colloids and gels, or with the problem of ceiiuiar movement and irritability, for all these and many more may find some application in the stuay of this disease. Ana similarly, if one is more immediately concerned with the understanding and prevention or amelioration of human disease, there are few diseases that are of more pressing social and economic importance at the present time. Arteriosclerosis and its accepted sequelae have come to constitute tne major cause of death in the more civilized parts of the world. It is a disease whose lethal potentialities have been exposed by the social and medical progress of the last 50 years. It is a disease of the world's ageing population.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pathology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Thomas and matthew Arnold : their significance for Canadian education.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The name of Arnold of Rugby is one which has become so hallowed not only by tradition but by convention that the question may well be asked why a further survey of his significance as an educator should be undertaken. Thomas Arnold was a man upon whom the white light of controversy beat while he lived, and whose works certainly lost nothing in fame and discussion after he had died. His dramatic and sudden death evoked not only a great biography which might well otherwise have been at least postponed and perhaps never prepared, but brought into vivid relief the personality and accomplishments of a man with whom his contemporaries may have disputed, but who felt his greatness, without defining it, while he livedo What Stanley had done in the two poignant years following Arnoldfs death, it was useless for anyone else to try to duplicate.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Arnold, Thomas, 1795-1842.
Arnold, Matthew, 1822-1888.
Education -- Canada.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Experimental gastric and duodenal ulcer, (b) Reconstructive surgery: experimental use of a skin-lined tube in the greater omentum.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The search for a satisfactory and complete explanation of acute and chronic ulcerations of the stomach and duodenum of man has been carried on by numerous investigators in both laboratories and clinics for many decades. Although much information has been obtained during the course of these varied investigations it is readily apparent that no all-embracing explanation of these lesions has been agreed upon, nor, as yet, has a theory been formulated which will successfully withstand criticism. This, in itself, suggests two chief possibilities. Firstly - that there is no single explanation of "peptic" ulcer. It may be a condition, the result of many factors, with now one, and then another, predominantly responsible. Secondly - that more factors remain to be brought to light in the future, one of which may be proven to be of paramount importance in the pathogenesis of peptic ulcer, with the presently-recognised factors secondary to or synergic with it. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Surgery.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A cobalt-tungsten deposit in the Sudbury district.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] The investigation is less complete than desired, chiefly because the writer has not been able to visit the property. Accordingly, no first-hand observations on the field relationships are possible. Furthermore, the suite of specimens on which the study Is based was not collected primarily for this purpose, and has certain deficiencies, e.g., the relatively unaltered county rock type away from the mineralized zone. Despite these limitations, the description of the unusual mineral association and some conclusions derived therefrom are regarded as worthwhile contributions.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geological Sciences.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Some physiological aspects of frozen vegetables.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A series of experiments has been conducted in which asparagus, beans, beet petioles and peas were frozen at three different rates. Apparatus was set up for the microscopic inspection of sections of frozen vegetable tissues and for the taking of photomicrographs of these sections. A series of forty-four photomicrographs is presented showing sections of fresh, frozen and thawed materials. Results indicate that in freezing vegetables the slower the speed, the larger are the ice crystals formed. It has been shown that ice forms in and around water conducting vessels to a greater extent than in neighbouring areas of undifferentiated parenchyma cells Injury to tissues is caused by the mechanical action of ice formation both intracellularly and extracellularly. It is concluded that in freezing asparagus, beans, beet-tops and peas the slower rates of freezing are not necessarily inferior to faster rates with regard to the quality of the final cooked product.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Frozen vegetables.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The toxic effect of linseed oil meal in chick rations.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Linseed oil meal is the most abundant vegetable protein supplement produced in Canada and hence occupies an important place in the livestock feed industry. By virtue of its conditioning effects and protein content, it is widely used in the feeding of larger animals including swine. In the latter case, meat meal or tankage is used as an additional protein supplement. In poultry rations however, even after the inclusion of animal protein supplements in amounts and of a quality normally considered adequate, it has not been possible to use linseed oil meal to any appreciable extent without inferior growth results.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Poultry Husbandry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A comparison of the theories of the educative process of Plato, Aristotle, Dewey and Whitehead.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The problem which is the subject of this study originated in part from a teaching device employed by one of the professors of the Education Department. It was his custom as he spoke of national systems of education, etc. in each case to represent diagramatically on the blackboard, the learner, his relation as a scholar to the life outside the school walls, and the avenues or sources of his learning. By virtually a process of induction, these components came to be seen to occupy the stage in every discussion of educational theory. Not only did they appear, but they offered convenient intellectual pegs on which to hang our thinking.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Whitehead, Alfred North, 1861-1947.
Education -- Philosophy.
Aristotle.
Dewey, John, 1859-1952.
Plato.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Protein metabolism in the rat under the influence of damage, endocrine substances and diet.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] The experiments to be presented in this thesis have been undertaken with the object of further studying the role played by the adrenal cortex in the protein metabolic changes following stress, as well as other factors which may have an influence upon these changes. The author claims to a "contribution to knowledge" lie in the belief that (1) the data to be presented provide a new interpretation for the changes in urinary nitrogen observed in the rat following adrenalectomy. (2) The data referable to urinary nitrogen changes following fracture lend support to the concept that the adrenal cortical hormone which plays a part in the process is ANTI ANABOLIC in nature. (3) It will be shown that while the adrenal cortical hormones appear to be necessary for the appearance of an increased nitrogen excretion following trauma, they are NOT essential for the mobilization of endogenous 3). protein in the protein depleted rat following food withdrawal, and that this phenomenon is not inhibited by the administration of an anabolic steroid hormone.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Medicine.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A study on the corn-gluten of stripper-starch.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The work presented in this study on the corn gluten of stripper-starch centres about two problems. The first problem was to determine the form in which the gluten is present in stripperstarch, and the nature of its association with the starch. The second problem was to find a neutral solvent capable of extracting the complete native corn gluten complex from the accompanying starch without dispersing the latter. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The theory of relativistic accelerators.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Acceleration methods nam be divided broadly into two classes. The first includes all methods in which a magnetic field is used to bend the particles during acceleration into spiral or circular orbits; in the second are all systems in which the particles are accelerated along straight paths.We shall be concerned here chiefly with the principal accelerators in the first class. The theoretical problems concerned with the stability of the orbital motion ere investigated. Account is also taken of the effects on the motion of loss of energy through radiation. The question of the maximum energy attainable in the various accelerating systems is considered.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mathematics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A study in gastro-intestinal motility.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Before discussion of the physiology of the gastro-intestinal motility it would be well to review briefly the anatomy of the region. The parts are: esophagus, stomach, small and large Intestine. The esophagus or gullet is, with the exception of pylorus, the narrowest and one of the most muscular parts of the whole alimentary tract. In the neck anteriorly lies the trachea and in the groove at each side, between the trachea and esophagus, the recurrent laryngeal nerve ascends to the larynx.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physiology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Action of vitamin P.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The investigations which led to the discovery of vitamin P were undertaken by Armentano, Szent-Gyorgyi and co-workers to determine why purified ascorbic acid, in contrast to the crude product, was a therapeutic failure in vascular purpura. Since earlier work on plants had shown that ascorbic acid was coupled with an essential flavone, the experimenters proceeded to isolate this substance. From about 200 kg of lemons or 70 L of lemon juice, approximately 2 g of flavone material could be obtained, which because of its yellow color and origin was named citrin.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physiology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A study of the diabase dykes of the Canadian shield.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This paper deals with the results of a study and review of the petrographical, stratigraphical, and structural characteristics of certain basic intrusives, generally distributed throughout the Canadian Shield, which are described as "diabase" dykks and sills. It is found that the cutting relationships reported afford positive evidence of at least four sequences of "diabase" intrusion. Except for degree of alteration, the sequences resemble each other so closely that positive age correlation on a petrographical basis is precluded. The dykes have predominant north west, north-south, and north a act trends. The writer concludes thab structural evidence suggests" the hypothesis that the dykes are emplaced in fissures which began opening in the crust above a basaltic substratum, along lines of weakness striking approximately north west, north-south, pnd north east, during stretching of the crust; and that surface trends have been modified somewhat by diversion of the magma into some pre-existing local fissures.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geological Sciences.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The reactions of N-dodecyl mercapton and potassium persulfate in emulsion systems.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] The present investigation was concerned with a few reactions which may occur In one of the most widely used polymerization processes, and It was hoped that their elucidation might clarify some of the factors governing the structure and properties of the polymer. This work could be discussed without reference to polymerization but it is felt that much of its interest and meaning would be lost in so doing. For this reason the more pertinent facts and theories of polymer reactions are included in what follows. Familiarity with the general field of polymer chemistry is assumed.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A study on the hypersensitivity in guinea pigs as induced by the inhalation of allergens.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] Much work has been done in animals using purely artificial means of inducing hypersensitivity. Only a few workers have attempted to simulate hypersensitivity in animals, as it occurs in humans. Therefore, the study o hypersensitivity In animals, produced in guinea pigs by inhalation of the antigenic substance, might well show features of both anaphylaxis in animals and allergy, (i.e. asthma) in humans. It was with these features in mind that the present problem was undertaken.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Medicine.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The effect of renal hypertension upon the development of experimental cholesterol artheriosclerosis in the rabbit.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] The work presented in this Thesis, it is hoped, will aid in clarifying some of the features of the relationship of experimental atherosclerosis to renal hypertension in animals and will, perhaps, throw some light on the relationship in man. Further, it may clarify some of the differences and similarities between experimental cholesterol arteriosclerosis in animals as compared to atherosclerosi in human beings.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pathology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: La convention collective et son extension juridique en général et en Québec plus particulièrement.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] En une première partie les principes théoriques qui gouvernent une convention collective en général et toute extension juridique de convention collective seront exposée ainsi qu'un essai de système idéal d'extension juridique prenant en considération et poussant ces principes jusqu'à leurs conclusions les plus rigoureuses. Dans la seconde partie, une étude pratique de la Loi de l a Convention Collective, dans la province de Québec offrira des points de comparaison avec cette étude théorique. Une troisième partie sera consacrée à une revue de l'attitude prise dans plusieurs législatures du monde devant cette question. Et une dernière partie sera consacrée à l'ébauche d'une critique constructive de notre loi québécoise, ainsi qu'à des considérations et conclusions générales.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Law.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies on the availability of major plant nutrients in open-hearth tapping slag and effects of application on soil properties.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Basic open-hearth tapping slag is a by-product in the manufacture of steel. This typo of slag is produced in the Maritime Provinces by the Dominion Steel & Coal Corporationat Sydney, Nova Scotia. Different types of slag have proven to be of great agricultural value in Great Britain, Germany, United States and Belgium. Tapping slag is produced in large quantities in Nova Scotia and, being an asset to the agricultural industry as a fertilizer on soils, it is of the utmost importance that its value to Maritime farmers be ascertained.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agricultural Chemistry.
